ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments:
Knowledge: new vocabulary and grammar, some Chinese literature (Lu Xun...), current debate topics in Chinese society (child-bearing rights, sexuality, illegal immigration, ...), Chinese films from the last 30 years

Skills: description, presentation, writing, reading...

Insights: Studying Chinese is very fun and I hope to continue in the future.

It will be hard for future courses to rival this one in terms of both the breadth and depth of content introduced. The supplied readings and accompanying discussions gave me the ability to discuss relevant and intriguing social issues (ranging from abortion rights to sexuality) in Chinese, something I'd never been able to do previously. In so doing, this course also helped me reassess my worldview by introducing perspectives absent from my education in English, giving me new insight into the opportunities that can be gained from being a language learner. In terms of skills, this course also challenged my speaking, listening, reading, and writing capabilities on a daily basis, although I wish the latter two had been focused on a bit more (specifically with regard to reading more primary sources and writing with more formal argumentation).
Continuation of Chinese.
Learned a lot about Chinese language, culture, and history
I improved my conversational skills, became more comfortable with lengthy descriptions, expanded my Chinese vocabulary, and increased my use of formal Chinese phrases and structures.
My Chinese skills improved greatly without being overly stressed with a high amount of homework.
This class was immensely helpful for my Chinese speaking and reading ability. Mostly focused on vocab and sentence structures.
A lot of new vocabulary, sentence structures, practice writing essays & giving presentations

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: the content was very well selected and fun, the teaching was great, and the workload was just right to encourage learning and challenge through a variety of tasks without being too heavy.

Weaknesses: not too many opportunities to converse in class or to speak spontaneously (presentations were very scripted), so this didn't allow for enough practice speaking naturally.

One of the major strengths of this course was its content. As discussed in 1. above, the supplied readings forced me to grapple with complex topics previously inaccessible to me in Chinese, encouraging deeper understanding and fostering greater maturity in my usage of the target language. I also thoroughly enjoyed the format of the in-person class meetings - the ability to have open, immersive discussion challenged my listening and speaking skills in a unique way.

I feel like the biggest weakness of this course was its unbalanced workload. Having to constantly prepare oral reports and skits put a strain on my sleep schedule and reduced the amount of time I had to prepare for other assignments - I feel like other forms of assessment are more time-effective for both the teachers and students involved. In particular, it would have been nice to substitute a few of the presentational projects for, say, argumentative essays, which would have aided students in developing their formal self-expression without a) detracting from discussion time and b) introducing overhead in terms of coordinating times to practice.
Great readings and movies. Class size is just right for good discussion.

Strengths: some very interesting topics. More manageable workload than 150/151.
Weaknesses: Repetitive.

One strength of this course was the many opportunities we had to discuss complex topics using newly learned vocabulary. I learned a lot of Chinese and information about Chinese history and society. I think it could have been helpful to have a bit more drilling of new structures during class time.
It is a very well balanced course. There are no major areas that need improvement, the teaching was excellent.

The class is very discussion based. Students are given lots of room to try out new vocabulary and voice their opinions about readings. However, the class does move quite quickly, and it can be hard to fully internalize all of the discussed content.
Strengths: clearly structured, low pressure environment, super kind professors! No weaknesses

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! great structure, content, and teaching.

I would recommend this course, but only if the student understands the time commitment they are making. The course content is splendid, but the sheer amount of projects assigned places harsh limits on the amount of time one can spend on other courses.
yes.
Yes!
I would recommend this course because I learned a lot of new phrases and words very quickly. I am learned how to discuss a lot of very relevant topics in Chinese society.
Absolutely. It will improve your Chinese and will not leave you feeling burned out.
Definitely! This class is so much fun, and really helped develop my Chinese.
Yes! Great way to improve your Chinese - I learned a lot in a low pressure environment.
